description: 1871, from the important Chinese port Shanghai, as a verb with reference to the former practice by some shippers on the West Coast of the United States of press-ganging crews for fishing or shipping in the Pacific Ocean.

entries.meaning: (often capitalized, dated) A breed of chicken with large bodies, long legs, and feathered shanks.

examples: The ‘shanghai’ is the glaring daub required by some frame-makers for cheap auctions. They are turned out at so much by the day's labor, or at from $12 to $24 a dozen, by the piece.

entries.meaning: (darts, often capitalized) A kind of dart game in which players are gradually eliminated ("shanghaied"), usually either by failing to reach a certain score in 3 quick throws or during a competition to hit a certain prechosen number and then be the first to hit the prechosen numbers of the other players.
examples: ‘Shanghai’ may be played by teams of 8, in pairs, individually, or, in fact, any number.

verbs.description: shanghai (third-person singular simple present shanghais, present participle shanghaiing, simple past and past participle shanghaied)

definitionGroups.group: (transitive) To force or trick someone to go somewhere or do something against their will or interest, particularly

entries.meaning: To press-gang sailors, especially (historical) for shipping or fishing work.
(US law enforcement slang) To trick a suspect into entering a jurisdiction in which they can be lawfully arrested.
(US military slang) To transfer a serviceman against their will.
examples: “Why, if you so loved and cherished the armed guard,” Captain Banning continued, “did you arrange for transfer?”“I never, sir! ... But he shanghaied me out of the armed guard pronto.”

entries.meaning: (transitive) To commandeer, hijack, or otherwise (usually wrongfully) appropriate a place or thing.
examples: Let's see if we can shanghai a room for a couple of hours.

description: From Scottish shangan, from Scottish Gaelic seangan, influenced by the Chinese city.

examples: Turn, turn thy shang~hay dread aside,Nor touch that little bird

verbs.description: shanghai (third-person singular simple present shanghais, present participle shanghaiing, simple past and past participle shanghaied)

entries.meaning: (Australia, New Zealand) To hit with a slingshot.
